column1: Geelong () is a port city located on Corio Bay and the Barwon River
column2: in the state of Victoria
column3: Australia.  Geelong is 75 kilometres (47 mi) south-west of the state capital
column4: Melbourne. It is the second largest Victorian city
column5: with an estimated urban population of 268
column6: 277 as of June 2018. It is also Australia's second fastest growing city. Geelong runs from the plains of Lara in the north to the rolling hills of Waurn Ponds to the south
column7: with Corio Bay to the east and the Barrabool Hills to the west. Geelong is the administrative centre for the City of Greater Geelong municipality
column8: which covers urban
column9: rural and coastal areas surrounding the city
column10: including the Bellarine Peninsula.Geelong was named in 1827
column11: with the name derived from the local Wathaurong Aboriginal name for the region
column13: thought to mean "land" or "cliffs" or  "tongue of land or peninsula". Geelong City is also known as the 'Gateway City' due to its central location to surrounding Victorian regional centres like Ballarat in the north west
column15: Great Ocean Road and Warrnambool in the southwest
column17: Colac and Winchelsea to the west
column18: and the state capital of Melbourne in the north east.

column1: The area was first surveyed in 1838
column2: three weeks after Melbourne. The post office was open by June 1840 (the second to open in the Port Phillip District).

column1: The first woolstore was erected in this period and it became the port for the wool industry of the Western District. During the gold rush
column2: Geelong experienced a brief boom as the main port to the rich goldfields of the Ballarat district. The city then diversified into manufacturing
column3: and during the 1860s
column4: it became one of the largest manufacturing centres in Australia with its wool mills
column5: ropeworks
column6: and paper mills.It was proclaimed a city in 1910
column7: with industrial growth from this time until the 1960s establishing the city as a manufacturing centre for the state
column8: and the population grew to over 100
column9: 000 by the mid-1960s. During the city's early years
column10: an inhabitant of Geelong was often known as a Geelongite
column12: derived from the city's nickname of "The Pivot"
column13: referencing the city's role as a shipping and rail hub for the area. Population increases over the last decade were due to growth in service industries
column14: as the manufacturing sector has declined. Redevelopment of the inner city has occurred since the 1990s
column15: as well as gentrification of inner suburbs
column16: and currently has a population growth rate higher than the national average.Today
column17: Geelong stands as an emerging health
column18: education and advanced manufacturing hub. The city's economy is shifting quickly and despite experiencing the drawbacks of losing much of its heavy manufacturing
column19: it is seeing much growth in other sectors
column20: positioning itself as one of the leading non-capital Australian cities. It is home to the Geelong Football Club
column21: the second oldest club in the Australian Football League.

column1: The area of Geelong and the Bellarine Peninsula was originally occupied by the Wathaurong Indigenous Australian tribe.The first nonindigenous person recorded as visiting the region was Lieutenant John Murray
column2: who commanded the brig HMS Lady Nelson. After anchoring outside Port Phillip Heads (the narrow entrance to Port Phillip
column3: onto which both Geelong and Melbourne now front)
column4: on 1 February 1802
column5: he sent a small boat with six men to explore. Led by John Bowen
column6: they explored the immediate area
column7: returning to Lady Nelson on 4 February. On reporting favourable findings
column8: Lady Nelson entered Port Phillip on 14 February
column9: and did not leave until 12 March. During this time
column10: Murray explored the Geelong area and
column11: whilst on the far side of the bay
column12: claimed the entire area for Britain. He named the bay Port King
column14: then Governor of New South Wales. Governor King later renamed the bay Port Phillip after the first governor of New South Wales
column15: Arthur Phillip. Arriving not long after Murray was Matthew Flinders
column16: who entered Port Phillip on 27 April 1802. He charted the entire bay
column18: believing he was the first to sight the huge expanse of water
column19: but in a rush to reach Sydney before winter set in
column20: he left Port Phillip on 3 May.

column2: Surveyor-General Charles Grimes arrived at Port Phillip in the sloop Cumberland and mapped the area
column3: including the future site of Geelong
column4: but reported the area was unfavourable for settlement and returned to Sydney on 27 February. In October of the same year
column5: HMS Calcutta led by Lieutenant Colonel David Collins arrived in the bay to establish the Sullivan Bay penal colony. Collins was dissatisfied with the area chosen
column6: and sent a small party led by First Lieutenant J.H. Tuckey to investigate alternate sites. The party spent 22 to 27 October on the north shore of Corio Bay
column7: where the first Aboriginal death at the hands of a European in Victoria occurred.The next European visit to the area was by the explorers Hamilton Hume and William Hovell. They reached the northern edge of Corio Bay – the area of Port Phillip that Geelong now fronts – on 16 December 1824
column8: and it was at this time they reported that the Aboriginals called the area Corayo
column9: the bay being called Djillong. Hume and Hovell had been contracted to travel overland from Sydney to Port Phillip
column10: and having achieved this
column11: they stayed the night and began their return journey two days later on 18 December.The convict William Buckley escaped from the Sullivan Bay settlement in 1803
column12: and lived among the Wathaurong people for 32 years on the Bellarine Peninsula. In 1835
column13: John Batman used Indented Head as his base camp
column14: leaving behind several employees whilst he returned to Tasmania (then known as Van Diemen's Land) for more supplies and his family. In this same year
column15: Buckley surrendered to the party led by John Helder Wedge and was later pardoned by Lieutenant-Governor Sir George Arthur
column16: and subsequently given the position of interpreter to the natives.

column2: three squatters
column3: David Fisher
column4: James Strachan
column5: and George Russell arrived on Caledonia and settled the area. Geelong was first surveyed by Assistant Surveyor W. H. Smythe three weeks after Melbourne
column6: and was gazetted as a town on 10 October 1838. There was already a church
column7: hotel
column8: store
column9: wool store
column10: and 82 houses
column11: and the town population was 545. By 1841
column12: the first wool had been sent to England and a regular steamer service was running between Geelong and Melbourne. Captain Foster Fyans was commissioned as the local Police Magistrate in 1837 and established himself on the Barwon River at the site of the area of present-day Fyansford. Fyans constructed a breakwater to improve the water supply to the city by preventing the salty lower reaches from mixing with fresh water and pooling water.  In 1839
column14: the newly appointed Assistant Protector of Aborigines (for the western district) sets up camp on the Barwon river near Fyans ford.

column1: The Geelong Keys were discovered around 1845 by Governor Charles La Trobe on Corio Bay. They were embedded in the stone in such a way that he believed that they had been there for 100–150 years
column2: possibly dropped by Portuguese explorers. In 1849
column3: Fyans was nominated as the inaugural Mayor of the Geelong Town Council. An early settler of Geelong
column4: Alexander Thomson
column5: for which the area of Thomson in East Geelong is named
column6: settled on the Barwon River
column7: and was Mayor of Geelong on five occasions from 1850 to 1858.

column1: Gold was discovered in nearby Ballarat in 1851
column2: causing the Geelong population to grow to 23
column3: 000 people by the mid-1850s. To counter this
column4: a false map was issued by Melbourne interests to new arrivals
column5: showing the quickest road to the goldfields as being via Melbourne. The first issue of the Geelong Advertiser newspaper was published in 1840 by James Harrison
column6: who also built the world's first ether vapour compression cycle ice-making and refrigeration machine in 1844
column7: later being commissioned by a brewery in 1856 to build a machine that cooled beer.

column1: The Geelong Hospital was opened in 1852
column2: and construction on the Geelong Town Hall commenced in 1855. Development of the Port of Geelong began with the creation of the first shipping channel in Corio Bay in 1853. The Geelong-to-Melbourne railway was built by the Geelong and Melbourne Railway Company in 1857. Rabbits were introduced to Australia in 1859 by Thomas Austin
column3: who imported them from England for hunting purposes at his Barwon Park property near Winchelsea. One of Geelong's best-known department stores
column4: Bright and Hitchcocks
column5: was established in 1861
column6: and the HM Prison Geelong built using convict labour
column7: was opened in 1864.In 1866
column8: Graham Berry started a newspaper
column9: the Geelong Register
column10: as a rival to the established Geelong Advertiser. When this proved unsuccessful
column11: he bought the Advertiser and made himself editor of the now-merged papers. Using the paper as a platform
column12: he was elected for West Geelong in 1869. In 1877
column15: and served as Victorian Premier in 1875
column17: and 1880–1881. On the Market Square in the middle of the city
column18: a clock tower was erected in 1856
column19: and an Exhibition Building was opened in 1879.

column1: The gold rush had seen Ballarat and Bendigo grow larger than Geelong in terms of population. Melbourne critics dubbed Geelong 'Sleepy Hollow'
column2: a tag that recurred many times in the following years. A number of industries became established in Geelong
column3: including Victoria's first woollen mill at South Geelong in 1868. In 1869
column4: the clipper Lightning caught fire at the Yarra Street pier and was cast adrift in Corio Bay to burn before finally sunk by artillery fire. Improvements to transport saw Geelong emerge as the centre of the Western District of Victoria
column5: with railway lines extended towards Colac in 1876
column6: and to Queenscliff in 1879. Construction of the Hopetoun shipping channel began in 1881 and completed in 1893.The Geelong Cup was first held in 1872
column7: and Victoria's first long-distance telephone call was made from Geelong to Queenscliff on 8 January 1878
column8: only one year after the invention of the device itself. Geelong was also the home of a prosperous wine industry until the emergence of the grapevine-eating insect Phylloxera vastatrix in 1885
column9: which killed the industry until the 1960s. Between 1886 and 1889
column10: the central business district's major banks and insurance companies erected new premises in a solid and ornate character. The existing Geelong Post Office was built during this time and the Gordon Technical College was established. Further industrial growth occurred with the Fyansford cement works established in 1890.The town became known as 'the Pivot' in the 1860s owing to its being a central rail and shipping hub to Melbourne

column1: The town of Geelong officially became a city on 8 December 1910. The city gained a number of essential services
column2: with electric light supplied by the Geelong Power Station starting in 1902
column3: the Geelong Harbour Trust was formed in December 1905
column4: and the Geelong Waterworks and Sewerage Trust formed in 1908. Electric trams began operation in 1912
column5: travelling from the city centre to the suburbs until their demise in 1956. The first of many stores on the Market Square was opened in 1913
column6: and the first Gala Day festival was held in 1916.Geelong's industrial growth accelerated in the 1920s: woollen mills
column7: fertiliser plants
column8: the Ford Motor Company's vehicle plant at Norlane
column9: and the Corio whisky distillery were all established in this period. The Geelong Advertiser radio station 3GL (now K-Rock) commenced transmission in 1930
column10: the Great Ocean Road was opened in 1932
column12: the T & G Building opened on the most prominent intersection in the city
column13: the corner of Ryrie and Moorabool Streets.

column2: Geelong had displaced Ballarat as Victoria's second-largest city.
one of the last Port Philip Bay steamers
column3: Edina
column4: made its final trip to Geelong
column5: ending a period of seaside excursions and contests for the fastest trip. The Eastern Beach foreshore beautification and pool was completed in 1939 after almost 10 years of work.On the eve of World War II
column6: the International Harvester works were opened beside Ford at North Shore
column7: along with a grain elevator at nearby Corio Quay
column8: and the Shell Australia oil refinery.

column1: Government housing was constructed in the suburbs of East Geelong
column2: Norlane
column3: North Shore
column4: and Corio from the 1950s. The banks of the Barwon River burst in 1952
column5: inundating nearby Belmont Common.

column1: Geelong continued to expand with Corio
column2: Highton
column3: and Belmont growing at such a rate that in February 1967
column4: Geelong accounted for 21% of private home development in Greater Melbourne. Private vehicles became the city's major mode of transport. The first parking meters in the city were introduced in 1961
column5: new petrol stations were constructed and the city's first supermarket
column6: operated by Woolworths
column7: opened in 1965. Later
column8: support came for Cycling in Geelong with Australia's first bike plan in 1977.[3] [4].

column1: Industrial growth continued with a second cement works operating at Waurn Ponds by 1964 and the Alcoa Point Henry aluminium smelter constructed in 1962.Federal government policy changes on tariff protection led to the closure of many Geelong industrial businesses from the 1970s. The woollen mills closed in 1974 and hectares of warehouse space in the city centre were left empty after wool-handling practices changed. The Target head office opened in North Geelong
column2: Deakin University was established at Waurn Ponds in 1974
column3: and the Geelong Performing Arts Centre opened in 1981. Later
column4: the Australian Animal Health Laboratory was opened in 1985
column5: and the National Wool Museum in 1988.Market Square
column6: the first enclosed shopping centre in the city
column7: was opened in 1985
column8: with neighbouring Bay City Plaza opened in 1988. The Pyramid Building Society
column9: founded in Geelong in 1959
column10: collapsed in 1990
column11: leaving debts of AU$1.3 billion to over 200
column13: and causing the Geelong economy to stagnate. On 18 May 1993
column14: the City of Greater Geelong was formed by the amalgamation of a number of smaller municipalities with the former City of Geelong. The Waterfront Geelong redevelopment
column16: was designed to enhance use and appreciation of Corio Bay and in 1995 the Barwon River overflowed in the worst flood since 1952.

column2: Avalon Airport was upgraded to accommodate interstate passenger travel
column3: providing a base for the low-cost airline Jetstar to serve the Melbourne and Geelong urban areas. Geelong is planned to expand towards the south coast
column4: with 2
column5: 500 hectares of land to become a major suburban development for 55
column7: 000 people
column8: known as Armstrong Creek. In 2006
column9: construction began on the Geelong Ring Road
column10: designed to replace the Princes Highway through Geelong from Corio to Waurn Ponds. It opened in 2009.

column1: More than AU$500-million-worth of major construction was under way in 2007. Major projects include the $150-million Westfield Geelong expansion works
column2: involving a flyover of Yarra Street
column3: the city's first Big W store
column4: and an additional 70 new speciality stores; the $37-million Deakin Waterfront campus redevelopment
column5: and the $23-million Deakin Medical School; the $50-million Edgewater apartment development on the waterfront; a number of multimillion-dollar office developments in the CBD; and a new $30-million aquatic centre in Waurn Ponds.Major developments within Geelong are advocated by the region's formal alliance
column6: G21 Geelong Region Alliance. The City of Greater Geelong and four other local municipalities form part of the alliance which identifies the Geelong region's priorities
column7: and advocates all levels of government for funding and implement the projects. G21 developed 'The Geelong Region Plan - a sustainable growth strategy' which was launched by Premier Brumby in 2007. It was the approved strategic plan for the Geelong region. In addition
column8: major projects such as the Geelong Ring Road Connections and duplication of the Princes Highway West obtained funding due to the combined efforts of the region's municipalities. As at May 2017
column9: a further 13 Priority Projects are planned for the Geelong region.

column1: The Victoria Government announced the relocation of the Transport Accident Commission headquarters from Melbourne to Geelong in October 2006
column2: which created 850 jobs and an annual economic benefit over $59 million to the Geelong region. The construction of the $80-million Brougham Street headquarters was completed in late 2008. In November 2008
column3: Ford Australia announced that its Australian-designed I6 engine would be re-engineered to meet the latest emissions regulations
column4: and that consequently the engine manufacturing plant would be upgraded (however
column5: all manufacturing of motor vehicles in Geelong and elsewhere throughout Australia ceased by 2017).

column1: A change to the city skyline is occurring with a number of modern apartment buildings on the Waterfront and central business district planned or under construction. On 10 July 2008
column2: approval was given for a $100-million twin-tower apartment complex of 16 and 12 floors to be built on Mercer St in the city's western edge. The towers will become the tallest buildings in the city
column3: taking the title from the Mercure Hotel. Further highrise developments are planned as part of the City of Greater Geelong's Geelong Western Edge strategic plan. A$17-million 11-story apartment tower has also recently been proposed to be built next to the Deakin Waterfront Campus.In 2012
column4: a design competition for a "city icon" was run for the City of Geelong by Deakin University and Senia Lawyers. The recipient of the prize and winning design entry was JOH Architects and their design titled "The Sea Dragon".

column1: Geelong's new Library and Heritage Centre opened to the public in November 2015. The new addition to Geelong offers new research facilities
column2: display areas and hosts Geelong's extensive heritage
column3: modern and Indigenous. The new library was awarded the Sir Zelman Cowen Award for Public Architecture in 2016.

column1: Currently Geelong is undergoing a major revival effort
column2: the Green Spine Project. The Green Spine project will connect Johnstone Park to the Botanic Gardens by a continuous line of trees via Malop Street. The redevelopment of Malop street will see the installation of separated bike lanes from both pedestrians and local traffic by greenery
column3: the design is an Australian first. This project includes the installation of art sculptures and street art throughout the city centre. Major redevelopments are also occurring at Johnstone Park
column4: with a new raingarden installation
column5: and Lt Malop Street is seeing more upgrades.In the suburbs Geelong West's Pakington Street is seeing major upgrades to its street appeal
column6: with new plantings and upgrades to many of the shops. Manifold Heights' Shannon Avenue will see redevelopment to make it more pedestrian friendly. To Geelong's north
column7: Rippleside is undergoing major changes
column8: with the ongoing development of Balmoral Quay which will see Rippleside Park and nearby St Helens Park connected via a waterfront footpath as well as beach restoration and a boat dock expansion.Recently new high rise buildings are being built giving Geelong more jobs and housing. Worksafe Victoria opened up a new 14-storey building on Malop st. It opened mid 2018 and was the tallest building until it was announced that two residential high rises would be built and completed in late 2019. They are called The Mercer and Miramar Apartments.

column1: Geelong is located on the shores of Corio Bay
column2: a south-western inlet bay of Port Phillip. During clear weather
column3: the Melbourne skyline is visible from areas of Geelong when viewed across Port Phillip. The Barwon River flows through the city to the south before entering Lake Connewarre and the Barwon River estuary at Barwon Heads before going into Bass Strait.Geologically
column4: the oldest rocks in the area date back to the Cambrian period 500 million years ago
column5: with volcanic activity occurring in the Devonian period 350 million years ago. In prehistoric times water covered much of the lowlands that are now Geelong
column6: with the Barwon River estuary located at Belmont Common
column7: the course of the river being changed when Mount Moriac erupted and lava was sent eastwards towards Geelong.To the east of the city are the Bellarine Hills and the undulating plains of the Bellarine Peninsula. To the west are the sandstone-derived Barrabool Hills and basalt Mount Duneed
column8: and the volcanic plains to the north of Geelong extend to the Brisbane Ranges and the You Yangs. Soils vary from sandy loam
column9: basalt plains
column10: and river loam to rich volcanic soils

column1: Many materials used to construct buildings were quarried from Geelong
column2: such as bluestone from the You Yangs and sandstone from the Brisbane Ranges. A small number of brown coal deposits exist in the Geelong region
column3: most notably at Anglesea
column4: where it has been mined to fuel Alcoa's Anglesea Power Station since 1969. Limestone has also been quarried for cement production at Fyansford since 1888
column5: and Waurn Ponds since 1964.

column2: including the following:

column1: Development in Geelong started on the shores of Corio Bay in what is now the inner city. Development later spread to the south towards the Barwon River
column2: and the hill of Newtown and Geelong West. Major development south of the river in Belmont did not start until the 1920s
column3: stimulated by the construction of a new bridge over the river in 1926
column4: and the extension of the Geelong tramway system in 1927. Industrial areas were traditionally located on the Corio Bay for port access
column5: or the Barwon River for waste disposal.

column1: In the interwar and post-World War II years
column2: heavy industry continued to establish itself in the flatter northern suburbs
column3: where today industries such as the Shell oil refinery and Ford Motor Company engine plant reside. Residential development also spread to Corio and Norlane in the north
column4: with new Housing Commission of Victoria estates built to cater for employees of the new industries. From the 1960s
column5: residential growth spread to the Highton hills in the south and North Geelong following prosperous industries like the gasworks
column6: followed by Grovedale in the 1970s. A number of light industrial areas were also established in Breakwater
column7: Moolap
column8: and South Geelong.Changing cargo-handling methods at the Port of Geelong left woolstores in inner Geelong unused
column9: redevelopment beginning in the 1980s with the expansion of Westfield Geelong towards Corio Bay
column10: and culminating in the Waterfront Geelong development. Gentrification of former working-class inner suburbs such as Geelong West
column12: and South Geelong has also occurred. Today
column13: the major residential growth corridors are north towards Lara
column15: and south towards Mount Duneed as the Armstrong Creek Growth Area.

column2: its surrounding coastline and countryside offer a diverse range of attractions
column3: with summer and early autumn attracting the highest number of tourists.

column1: - Dog Rocks Flora and Fauna Sanctuary
- Portarlington (Port Phillip Ferries now operate a service between Portarlington and Docklands)
- Searoad Ferries service (between Queenscliff and Sorrento)
- The Bellarine Railway (operating between Drysdale and Queenscliff)
- The Geelong Library and Heritage Centre

column2: yet still offers four distinct seasons. It has a temperate oceanic climate (Cfb in the Köppen climate classification) with dominant westerly winds
column3: variable clouds
column4: moderate precipitation
column5: warm summers
column6: and mild to cool winters. February is the hottest month and July is the coldest. The highest temperature recorded was 47.4 °C (117.3 °F) on 7 February 2009 during a two-week-long heat wave
column7: with the lowest of −4.4 °C (24.1 °F) recorded on 5 August 1997. The average annual rainfall is around 520 mm (20.5 in)
column8: which makes Geelong the driest sizeable city in Australia
column9: owing to the pronounced rain shadow of the Otway Ranges to the southwest. Within the city
column10: rainfall shows a strong gradient from south to north
column11: so that the southernmost suburbs can receive around 700 mm (28 in) whilst more northerly Lara receives as little as 425 mm (17 in)
column12: which is the lowest rainfall in southern Victoria.

column3: 000 people in the Geelong region
column4: with manufacturing and processing industries providing around 15
column5: 000 jobs
column6: followed by 13
column7: 000 in retail
column8: and 8
column9: 000 in health and community services.Geelong's major employers were the Ford Motor Company engine plant in Norlane (closed in 2016)
column10: aircraft maintenance at Avalon Airport
column11: the head office of retail chain Target Australia(until 2018)
column12: the Bartter (Steggles) chicken processing plant and the Shell oil refinery at Corio. GMHBA Limited
column14: is headquartered in Geelong.The Geelong region attracted over 6 million tourists during 2001. Major tourist attractions include the Waterfront Geelong precinct and Eastern Beach on the shores of Corio Bay
column15: and the National Wool Museum in the city
column16: and more than 30 historical buildings listed on the Victorian Heritage Register. The Geelong area hosts regular international events which are also tourist drawcards

column1: Geelong has a number of shopping precincts in the CBD and surrounding suburbs. The two main shopping centres are located in the CBD - Westfield Geelong and Market Square
column2: with smaller centres in the suburbs including Belmont Village and Waurn Ponds Shopping Centre in the south
column3: Bellarine Village in Newcomb in the east
column4: and Corio Shopping Centre in the north. The opening of the major shopping centres has caused a decline in strip shopping on Moorabool Street
column5: with many empty shops and few customers. Geelong is also home to Mitre 10's largest franchisees - Fagg's - operating five stores across the town and employing over 160 people.

column1: These major research laboratories are located in the Geelong area: the CSIRO Australian Animal Health Laboratory in East Geelong
column2: CSIRO Division of Textiles and Fibres Technology in Belmont
column3: and the Marine and Freshwater Resources Institute at Queenscliff.The scheduled closure of Ford's Australian manufacturing base in 2016 was confirmed in late May 2013. Headquartered in the Victorian suburb of Broadmeadows
column4: the company had registered losses of AU$600 million over the five years prior to the announcement. It was noted that the corporate fleet and government sales that accounted for two-thirds of large
column5: local car sales in Australia were insufficient to keep Ford's products profitable and viable in Australia.Following the decision by the Royal Dutch Shell fuel corporation to close its Geelong refinery in April 2013
column6: a third consecutive annual loss was recorded for Shell's Australian refining and fuel marketing assets. Revealed in June 2013
column7: the writedown is worth AU$203 million
column8: and was preceded by a $638-million writedown in 2012 and a $407-million writedown in 2011 after the closure of the Clyde refinery in Sydney.In April 2016 Target announced that it would be moving its headquarters out of North Geelong to Williams Landing in Melbourne's west.

column3: 000 people resided in 68
column4: 000 households. The median age of persons in Geelong was 37 years. About 19.4% of the population of Geelong were children aged between 0–14 years
column5: and 26.6% were persons aged 55 years and over. Each dwelling is on average occupied by 2.59 persons
column6: slightly lower than the state and national averages. The median household income was $901 per week
column7: $121 less than the state average
column8: partly due to higher reliance on manufacturing for employment. The population of Geelong is growing by 2500 people each year
column9: and the City of Greater Geelong had the highest rate of building activity in Victoria outside metropolitan Melbourne.About 78.4% of people from Geelong are Australian-born
column10: with the most common overseas birthplaces being: England (3.6%)
column14: and Scotland (0.8%). Around 14.2% of households speak a language other than English in the home. Notable ethnic groups in the city are the Croatian community
column15: who first came to the city in the 1850s and with migration since World War II are now the largest Croatian community in Australia
column16: and the German settlers who founded Germantown (now Grovedale) in 1849 to escape repression in Prussia for their Lutheran faith.

column1: The 2006 census found the most common religious affiliation in Geelong was Catholicism at 29.4%. St. Mary of the Angels Basilica is the largest congregation in the city. Other affiliations of resident of Geelong include no religion 20.5%
column2: Anglican 14.6%
column3: Uniting Church 7.9%
column4: and Presbyterian and Reformed at 4.3%. The city has a large number of traditional Christian churches
column5: as well as Orthodox Christian churches in the northern suburbs.

column2: the Geelong region is covered by the City of Greater Geelong. The council was created in 1993 as an amalgamation of a number of other municipalities in the region
column3: with the council chambers located at the Geelong Town Hall in central Geelong. The City is made up of four wards - Brownbill (central Geelong and inner suburbs)
column4: Bellarine
column5: Kardinia (southern Geelong
column6: south of the Barwon River) and Windermere (northern suburbs). Brownbill
column7: Kardinia and Bellarine are each represented by three councillors
column8: whereas Windermere is represented by two.From 2012 to 2016
column9: the Mayor of Geelong was directly elected by the public to a four-year term. Entrepreneur and former paparazzo Darryn Lyons held this position from 2013 to 2016.On 16 April 2016
column10: the Victorian Government dismissed the Mayor and Councillors of the Greater Geelong City Council
column11: following a Commission of Inquiry which found that the council is riven with conflict
column12: unable to manage Geelong's economic challenges
column13: has dysfunctional leadership and has a culture of bullying. The government appointed administrators to run the council until council elections are held in 2017.In state politics
column14: the Legislative Assembly districts of Geelong
column17: and Bellarine cover the Geelong area. Lara is a safe Labor seat. Geelong and Bellarine are generally more marginal
column18: though lean more towards Labor whereas South Barwon is a marginal seat that tends to lean towards the Liberal Party. As of the 2018 Victorian State Election
column19: all four of these electorates are held by the Australian Labor Party. On 12 February 2020
column20: Minister for Planning Richard Wynn established Geelong Authority to advise on strategies to attract investment to central Geelong and on major planning applications to help create jobs and drive growth in Geelong. The committee is chaired by Roz Hansen (Urban Planner) and consists of Mark Edmonds (Chairman of Geelong Chamber of Commerce)
column23: Jill Smith (General Manager of Geelong Arts Centre) and Rory Costelloe (Executive Director of Villawood Properties).In federal politics
column24: the House of Representatives seats - the Division of Corio and Division of Corangamite cover the Geelong region. Corio roughly covers the northern half of Geelong and has been a safe Australian Labor Party since the 1970s
column25: but was previously the seat of Richard Casey
column26: a leading conservative Cabinet member in the 1930s and later Governor-General
column28: a former cycling champion and a prominent minister in the 1960s.  It was also the seat of Gordon Scholes
column29: who was Speaker during the Whitlam government. Corangamite
column30: which roughly includes the southern half of Geelong as well as the Bellarine Peninsula
column31: has traditionally been safe for the Liberal Party
column32: but has become more marginal in recent years due to demographic changes. Corangamite had been a safe seat for the Liberal Party and its predecessors from the 1930s through the 2000s.  Future Prime Minister of Australia James Scullin served one term in this seat in the 1910s. It was won by the Australian Labor Party at the 2019 federal election.

column1: The Royal Geelong Show is held each year at the Geelong Showgrounds. Other events include Pako Festa (held annually in February)
column2: Gala Day Parade (annual event that celebrated its 96th year in 2012) and Family Fun Day (held annually as part of the Gala Day celebrations)
column3: and the Geelong Heritage Festival that is run by the local branch of the National Trust.Geelong hosts Victoria's only international photographic salon 'VIGEX' every two years. VIGEX is an acronym for "VIctoria Geelong EXhibition" and the inaugural event was held in 1980. The Australian Photographic Society
column4: the world governing body of exhibition photography the International Federation of Photographic Art and the Victorian Association of Photographic Societies are patrons of the biennial photographic salon.Geelong's History is preserved through both the Geelong Historical Society
column5: and the associated Geelong Heritage Centre for which a substantial new building construction of which commenced in 2015.Geelong hosts international digital conference Pivot Summit which was headlined by Apple Co-founder Steve Wozniak in 2017.

column1: Geelong is home to a number of pubs
column2: nightclubs
column3: and live-music venues. The city is also the birthplace or starting point for a number of notable Australian bands and musicians
column4: such as Barry Crocker
column5: Gyan Evans
column6: Magic Dirt
column7: Jeff Lang
column8: Denis Walter
column9: Chrissy Amphlett
column10: and Helen Garner.Geelong also hosts music festivals such as the Queenscliff Music Festival
column14: and National Celtic Festival. The city's prominent cultural venues are the Geelong Performing Arts Centre (commonly known as "GPAC")
column15: the 1500-seat Costa Hall auditorium and the Geelong Art Gallery.

column2: the oldest newspaper title in Victoria and the second-oldest in Australia
column3: was established in 1840. The free Geelong Independent and Geelong News are the city's other major newspapers.

column1: Geelong is part of the Melbourne television licence area
column2: and receives all of the free-to-air stations from Melbourne
column3: including ABC
column4: SBS
column5: Seven
column6: Nine
column7: Ten
column8: and the community channel C31. The Geelong region also receives cable and satellite television services through operators Foxtel and Neighbourhood Cable.

column1: The local radio stations are K-Rock (rock and pop music)
column2: Rhema FM (Christian community station)
column3: Hot Country Radio (country music station)
column4: The Pulse (community station)
column5: 3GPH (radio reading service)
column6: and Bay FM (adult contemporary). The transmitters for K-Rock
column7: The Pulse
column8: Rhema FM
column9: and Bay FM are located at a shared transmitter site on Mount Bellarine
column10: near Drysdale. Most Melbourne-based radio stations can also be received clearly in the Geelong region.

column1: Geelong has inspired many visual artists
column2: with several celebrated works depicting the city
column3: including Eugene von Guerard
column4: who depicted early Geelong in sketches and oil paintings such as "View of Geelong".

column1: Geelong is occasionally used as a filming location. The region was used as the setting of the SeaChange television series
column2: filmed on location at Barwon Heads between 1998 and 2002. The city has also been the filming location of a number of feature films
column3: including the final scenes On the Beach (1959) at Barwon Heads; Mad Max (1979) around Lovely Banks; Lara
column4: Everynight ... Everynight (1994) at HM Prison Geelong; Ned Kelly (2003); Ghost Rider (2007) at the Little River Earth Sanctuary December Boys (2007) in South Geelong at Kardinia Pool
column5: ; and Knowing (2008) on the Geelong Ring Road. The action film The Ninja Immovable Heart was largely filmed on location in and around Geelong. Most recently
column6: The Dressmaker (2015) was filmed in and around Little River.

column1: Two ships of the Royal Australian Navy have been named after Geelong: HMAS Geelong (J201) and HMAS Geelong (FCPB 215).
The 2011 movie Contagion mentions the Australian Animal Health Laboratory located in Geelong.
Geelong is served by a number of public and private schools that cater to local and overseas students. Over 40
column2: 000 primary and secondary students are enrolled in schools in Geelong
column3: with another 27
column4: 000 students enrolled in tertiary and further education programs. The first schools in Geelong were established when the town was settled from the 1850s
column5: among them were the historic private schools The Geelong College and Geelong Grammar School
column6: where HRH Charles
column7: Prince of Wales spent two terms in 1966.

column1: Geelong is also home to the oldest state secondary school in Victoria
column2: Geelong High School
column3: which has been serving the community since 1905
column4: for over 100 years.

column1: The Gordon Memorial Technical College opened in 1888
column2: and is known today as the Gordon Institute of TAFE. In 1976
column3: the Gordon Institute was divided into two parts
column4: with academic courses becoming part of the newly formed Deakin University based at the Waurn Ponds campus. Deakin University enrolled its first students at its Waurn Ponds campus in 1977. Today
column5: the university is located on a 365-ha site at Waurn Ponds and has over 1
column6: 000 staff and over 4
column7: 000 on-campus students. The university also has a campus located on the waterfront of Corio Bay in the Geelong CBD
column8: a campus in Burwood
column9: Melbourne
column10: and a campus in Warrnambool
column11: in Western Victoria. From 2008 the campus at Waurn Ponds also has been home to Victoria's first regional medical school.

column1: The major public hospital is Geelong Hospital on Ryrie Street
column2: which services the entire region
column3: and the largest private hospital is the nearby St John of God Health Care centre on Myers Street. Prominent healthcare services include Geelong Health (Geelong West) and Barwon Health. Also a comprehensive acute and rehabilitation not-for-profit private hospital is currently being built
column4: adjacent to the Waurn Ponds campus of Deakin University
column5: due to open mid-2016. The new and modern Epworth Hospital is now open near the Deakin University at Waurnponds and is located at 1 Epworth Place
column6: Waurn Ponds VIC 3216.

column1: Water storage and supply in Geelong is managed by Barwon Water
column2: a Victoria government-owned urban water corporation. Geelong is supplied with water from three river systems: the Barwon
column3: the East Moorabool
column4: and the West Moorabool Rivers. The catchment areas are the Brisbane Ranges to Geelong's north-west
column5: and the Otway Ranges to the south-west. The first water supplies to Geelong were from the Stony Creek reservoirs near Steiglitz
column6: but
column7: as of 2010
column8: Geelong
column9: together with Ballarat
column10: consumes about 70% of the Moorabool River's water flow. Sewage from Geelong and district is treated at the Black Rock Treatment Plant at Breamlea and then discharged into Bass Strait.

column1: Geelong was first supplied with electricity in 1902 when the Geelong power station opened on the corner of Yarra and Brougham Streets. Later known as Geelong A
column2: the power station was rebuilt in 1920 to increase the capacity
column3: with the station continued operating until 1961. In 1936
column4: Geelong was connected to the state electrical grid. The Geelong B power station at North Geelong opened in 1954
column5: and was closed in 1970 due to the much higher efficiency of the power stations in the Latrobe Valley. The supply of piped coal gas in Geelong started in 1860 by the Geelong Gas Company. The gasworks were located in North Geelong next to the North Geelong railway station. Geelong was converted to natural gas in 1971
column6: with the Geelong Gas Company being taken over by the Gas and Fuel Corporation of Victoria on 30 June 1971.

column1: The main form of transportation in Geelong is the automobile. Geelong is well-connected by roads to all of south-west Victoria
column2: to Melbourne by a major-arterial the Princes Freeway (M1) with three or four lanes in each direction
column3: to Warrnambool by the Princes Highway (A1)
column4: the Bellarine Peninsula by the Bellarine Highway (B110)
column5: Ballarat by the Midland Highway (A300)
column6: and to Hamilton by the Hamilton Highway (B140). The $380-million Geelong Ring Road (an extension of the Princes Freeway) bypasses the greater Geelong urban area exiting the Princes Highway near Corio to rejoin the highway at Waurn Ponds. The "Lewis Bandt Bridge"
column7: named in honour of the Ford Australia engineer who is credited as the inventor of the ute (1934)
column8: in Geelong is a feature of the new road.

column1: Avalon Airport is located about 15 km (9.3 mi) to the north-east of the city of Geelong in the suburb of Avalon. It was established in 1953 for the production of military aircraft. It was also used for the repair of commercial aircraft
column2: and for pilot training. Avalon Airport has also been home to low-cost airline Jetstar Airways since 2004. Flights to Sydney use the airport and in June 2015
column3: Jetstar announced it would fly to the Gold Coast daily from Avalon Airport commencing October 2015. Avalon Airport is the venue for 'Thunder Down Under' Australian International Airshow every other year.

column1: Avalon Airport now has international flights with Air Asia to and from Kuala Lumpur.
Geelong is a major hub for rail transport in Victoria
column2: having frequent services to and from Melbourne
column3: and being at the junction of the Geelong line
column4: Warrnambool V/Line rail service
column5: Western standard gauge line
column6: and the Geelong-Ballarat railway line. Eight passenger railway stations are in the urban area
column7: all along the Warrnambool line and served by V/Line trains. The Geelong line provides passenger services to Melbourne in the off-peak with trains departing Geelong every 20 minutes on weekdays
column8: with more frequent services at peak times. According to V/Line
column9: the Geelong line carries more passengers than any other regional rail line in Australia. None of the lines are electrified and all trains servicing Geelong are diesel powered.

column1: Geelong's currently operating stations include Little River
column2: Lara
column3: Corio
column4: North Shore
column5: North Geelong
column6: Geelong
column7: South Geelong
column8: Marshall and Waurn Ponds.

column2: a rail line connected Geelong city to the Bellarine Peninsula through to Queenscliff
column3: ceasing to operate as a regular passenger service in 1976. The Bellarine Railway operates a section of the line between Drysdale and Queenscliff as a tourist attraction.

column1: Passenger services run to Warrnambool three times daily
column2: connecting Geelong with Colac
column3: Terang
column4: and Camperdown
column5: as well as Warrnambool. Great Southern Rail's The Overland service between Melbourne and Adelaide stops at the standard-gauge platform provided at North Shore station. It runs six days a week
column6: with three services to Adelaide and three to Melbourne. Freight trains also operate from Melbourne to Geelong serving local industries
column7: as well as to Warrnambool and other western Victorian towns. The main Melbourne-Adelaide standard-gauge line is a heavily used interstate freight route.

column2: Myki
column3: was implemented on rail services between Marshall and Melbourne on 29 July 2013.The Victorian government is currently in process of land acquisition and inspection for a potential Torquay rail line which would service both Torquay and the Armstrong Creek growth corridor.

column1: The Port of Geelong is located on the shores of Corio Bay
column2: and is the sixth-largest seaport in Australia by tonnage. Major commodities include crude oil and petroleum products
column3: export grain
column4: woodchips
column5: alumina imports
column6: and fertiliser. The Bellarine Peninsula has been linked to the Mornington Peninsula since 1987 by the Searoad ferry
column7: which runs every hour using two roll-on/roll-off ferries between Queenscliff and SorrentoPort Phillip Ferries began operating twice daily services between Portarlington and Melbourne Docklands in November 2016. Three years later overcrowding on trains led to a similar service being introduced from Geelong to Docklands. The services are popular with both tourists and commuters
column8: providing an alternative access for Geelong and the Bellarine Peninsula to Melbourne. The 36-metre-long catamaran ferries seat over 400 passengers
column9: provide a comfortable vantage point to enjoy the sights of Port Phillip. The introduction of the Portarlington service led to a major revamp of the local pier
column10: with pier extensions and a protective rock wall installed.

column1: A bus network covering the city centre and most surrounding suburbs provides public transport. Until June 2015 they were operated under the umbrella of the Geelong Transit System. Public Transport Victoria contracts CDC Geelong and McHarry's Buslines to provide Geelong's bus services and bus services to Torquay and the Bellarine Peninsula. V/Line services link Geelong with Ballarat
column2: Daylesford
column3: Bendigo
column4: Apollo Bay
column5: the Great Ocean Road
column6: the Twelve Apostles
column7: and Warrnambool.

column1: Taxi services in Geelong are provided by Geelong Taxi Network
column2: a newly formed depot following the effective merger of Bay City Cabs and Geelong Radio Cabs in July 2007.

column1: The majority of the network covers the city and suburban areas of the city
column2: with "urban" classification for the vehicles in use. The Bellarine Peninsula
column3: and Torquay areas
column4: although part of Geelong Taxi Network
column5: are both covered by separate "country" classification taxis. Often
column6: disputes occur in regards to different taxis from one licence area
column7: picking up work from either of the other two licence areas
column8: which is illegal in most circumstances under current taxi regulations in Victoria. Call centre and radio dispatch services for the new combined network are provided by Silver Top Taxis in Melbourne.

column1: Geelong also has many kilometres of bicycle trails including the:

column2: Corio Quay to Limeburners Point

column1: - Barwon River trail- 20 km between Fyansford and South Geelong
- Bellarine Rail Trail is a 32 km path between South Geelong and Queenscliffe.- Cowies Creek Trail
- Ted Wilson trail- Follows the Geelong Ring Road for 12 km between Corio to Hamlyn Heights

column2: Separation Street
column3: North Geelong through to the Fyansford Cement Works

column1: - Waurn Ponds trail offers follows over 6 km of the Waurn Ponds creek
Geelong is home to the Geelong Football Club Australian Football League team
column2: the second-oldest AFL club and one of the oldest in the world. Until South Melbourne relocated to Sydney in 1981
column3: it was the only VFL/AFL club to exist outside of the greater Melbourne metropolitan area. It continues to participate in the national competition today
column4: based at Kardinia Park stadium
column5: and also fields a reserves side in the Victorian Football League. The club won the 2007 grand final against Port Adelaide by 119 points
column6: the biggest grand final winning margin in history and the first Geelong premiership victory for 44 years. The club also won the 2009 and 2011 AFL grand finals held at the Melbourne Cricket Ground. Three independent football leagues are also running in the area
column7: the Geelong Football League
column8: the Geelong & District Football League
column9: and the Bellarine Football League.The Arena stadium in North Geelong is the home of the Geelong Supercats basketball team
column10: and was also used during the 2006 Commonwealth Games for basketball games. Geelong's Basketball/Netball Centre is home to another basketball team from the region

column1: The city co-hosted the 2003 FIBA Oceania Championship where Australia's national basketball team won the gold medal.
North Geelong Warriors FC are the region's primary soccer club
column2: playing in the National Premier Leagues Victoria competition. The club played in the Victorian Premier League from 1992 to 1997 and in the top tier of the NPL in 2015. Other soccer clubs include Northern based Geelong Rangers FC
column3: Geelong SC
column4: Corio SC
column5: Lara United FC and Southern based Surf Coast SC.

column1: Geelong Raiders Rugby League Football Club
column2: an Australian rugby league football club based in Newtown
column3: Victoria
column4: compete in the Victorian Rugby League competition.

column2: the Geelong Racing Club
column3: which schedules around 22 race meetings a year
column4: including the Geelong Cup meeting in October. The Geelong Cup was first run in 1872
column5: and is considered one of the most reliable guides to the result of the Melbourne Cup. It also has a picnic horse-racing club
column6: Geelong St Patricks Racing Club
column7: which holds its one race meeting a year in February.Geelong Harness Racing Club conducts regular meetings at its racetrack at Corio
column8: and the Geelong Greyhound Racing Club holds regular meetings.The Geelong Baseball Centre in Waurn Ponds is home of the Geelong Baycats. The Baycats are the only provincial team in Baseball Victoria's Division One competition and were the 2005/2006 State Champions. The Geelong Baseball Centre has hosted a number of National Championships
column9: the 2002 Women's World Championships and was home to the Chiba Lotte Marines for spring training in 2005 and 2006.

column1: The Geelong Tennis League is conducted every Saturday with a senior and junior competition. Each year the summer competition runs from October to March (with a summer holiday break) and the winter competition runs from late April to late August. Teams are based in the Geelong
column2: Surf Coast and Bellarine regions. Approximately each season there are 15 senior sections and 24 junior sections each with eight teams in each.

column1: The Eastern Beach foreshore and nearby Eastern Gardens regularly host internationally televised triathlons
column2: and annual sports car and racing car events such as the Geelong Speed Trials.Corio Bay is also host to many sailing and yachting events. Geelong also has many golf courses
column3: sporting and recreation ovals
column4: and playing fields
column5: as well as facilities for water skiing
column6: rowing
column7: fishing
column8: hiking
column9: and greyhound and harness racing.

column1: Geelong Athletics holds competitions during both the summer and winter
column2: including high-profile events such as Victorian and sometimes national and international track and field meets.

column1: Geelong is home to Australia's largest indoor skate park
column2: and has "more skate parks per capita than any other municipality in Australia."Geelong is also the birthplace of Bev Francis
column3: an IFBB professional Australian female bodybuilder
column4: powerlifter
column5: and national shot put champion.The Cadel Evans Great Ocean Road Race
column6: named in honor of the Tour de France winner and 2009 World Champion starts in the city. It then goes through Barwon Heads on the Bellarine Peninsula
column7: passing by the famous surf beach of Bells Beach in Surf Coast Shire and continuing along the Great Ocean Road. The race then heads via rolling hills back to Geelong for three circuits of the city before a waterfront finish. The race generally suits puncheurs who are capable of getting into breakaways and can easily climb short
column8: steep hills.
